awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Middle Grades Students' Capacity to Develop and Communicate Their Mathematical Understanding of Big Ideas Using Digital Inscriptional Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goal of this project is to help middle school students deepen and communicate their understanding of mathematics. The project will develop and test a digital platform for middle school mathematics classrooms. The digital platform will allow students to collaboratively create representations of their mathematics thinking, incorporate ideas from other students, and share their work with the class. The digital learning environment makes use of a problem-centered mathematics curriculum that evolved from extensive development, field-testing and evaluation, and is widely used in middle schools. The research will also contribute to understanding about the design and innovative use of digital resources and collaboration in classrooms as an increasing number of schools are drawing on these kinds of tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project will support students to collaboratively construct, manipulate, and interpret shared representations of mathematics using digital inscriptional resources. The research activities will significantly enhance our understanding of student learning in mathematics in three important ways. The project will report on how (1) evidence of student thinking is made visible through the use of digital inscriptional resources, (2) student inscriptions are documented, discussed, and manipulated in collaborative settings, and (3) students' conceptual growth of big mathematical ideas grows over time. An iterative design research process will incorporate four phases of development, testing and revision, and will be conducted to study student use of the digital learning space and related inscriptional resources. Data sources will include: classroom observations and artifacts, student and teacher interviews and surveys, student assessment data, and analytics from the digital platform. The process will include close collaboration with teachers to understand the implementation and create revisions to the resources.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Knowing how students develop and communicate their understanding of big mathematical ideas is critically important for researchers, teachers, and curriculum developers. As students learn, particularly when they do so by working together in collaborative group settings, they create and make use of representations of their thinking, such as written text, graphical displays, tables, equations, diagrams, maps, and charts. Sharing, combining, and modifying such representations as they work together is an important aspect of students’ collaborative learning. Understanding how students create and use these representations and how they evolve over time provides important insight into the processes of learning and ways to better support learning in different contexts.

This project studied how such representations make middle school students’ thinking about mathematical ideas visible. It did so by researching how students discussed and manipulated them in collaborative settings and how these related to the conceptual growth of big mathematical ideas. The project developed and implemented a digital platform for collaborative mathematical learning, and investigated the ways the platform supports students in developing, exchanging, and modifying shared mathematical representations over time.

The project platform includes embedded problems from Connected Mathematics Project (CMP) curriculum units, provides dedicated digital student workspaces, and supplies “just-in-time” student supports and a teacher dashboard. The platform logs underlying information about student and teacher interactions with the platform for research use. By implementing the platform and studying its use, the project established and refined usability and design characteristics for supporting small-group collaborative learning of mathematics via digital platforms.

The project also generated and refined a theoretical framework allowing researchers to characterize and analyze how students create and work with shared representations related to their mathematics learning within digital environments. Continuing work by project partners is applying this framework to the analysis of student learning and use of representations from classroom testing sessions. This will shed light on how digital technologies can help students deepen and make visible their understanding of mathematics by supporting students in collaboratively constructing, manipulating, and interpreting shared mathematical representations.
